name: stat
shortDescription: display file or file system status
longDescription: Display file or file system status.

options.name: dereference
options.description: Change how ‘stat’ treats symbolic links.  With this option, ‘stat’ acts on the file referenced by each symbolic link argument. Without it, ‘stat’ acts on any symbolic link argument directly.

options.name: file-system
options.description: Report information about the file systems where the given files are located instead of information about the files themselves.  This option implies the ‘-L’ option.

options.name: format
options.description: Use FORMAT rather than the default format.  FORMAT is automatically newline-terminated, so running a command like the following with two or more FILE operands produces a line of output for each operand: $ stat --format=%d:%i / /usr 2050:2 2057:2

options.name: printf
options.description: Use FORMAT rather than the default format.  Like ‘--format’, but interpret backslash escapes, and do not output a mandatory trailing newline.  If you want a newline, include ‘\n’ in the FORMAT. Here’s how you would use ‘--printf’ to print the device and inode numbers of ‘/’ and ‘/usr’: $ stat --printf='%d:%i\n' / /usr 2050:2 2057:2

options.name: terse
options.description: Print the information in terse form, suitable for parsing by other programs.
